content.description:
"A bolted boulder problem, but good fun nonetheless" -squamish select description



Just left of Credulous Hedgehog starting under the small roof

4 bolts

A very short route ending at a good ledge.  Middle of the West Face.
Middle route in the short section of cleaned rock. 3 Bolts

Very delicate movements required.


bolts

All the action is in the first two bolts, with a V4ish boulder problem starting right off the ground. There is a roughly 15mm hole drilled in the wall halfway between the first and second bolt, that provides the key mono. Above the second bolt is pleasant 5.9ish slabby climbing to the anchors. Shares anchor with Railton Road, so easy to TR after leading that route.

According to the FA:

"There used to be a metal box conduit on this line, enclosing cable leading to a base station on the hydro tower above the cliff. There are remnants of the conduit retaining bolts in places."

Starts on top of two, meter wide flakes on the ground right below where they fell off the wall. A few meters right of the chimney.
10 bolts to chains

Fun climb in Electric Avenue

Electric Avenue West Side between The Monatude (5.10d) and St. Elmo's Fire (5.8). 
Bolts with anchor at the top

A very easy, short route on the West Face. Middle of the West face, in a short section of clean rock.
Right-most route in the cleaned area. 4 Bolts

Crux is close to the start of the route. 

Electric Avenue West Side between Nihilist Porcupin (5.12c) and Tyrannosauress (5.11c). 
Bolts with anchors at the top

Leftmost route on the south wall that is around the corner from the West side. 

Bottom lower angle section has nice flowy movement. This leads to a crux through the steeper terrain up top. I thought this was the best route on this section of the wall

15 bolts to chains

Rightmost route of four on the south-facing section of wall that is around the corner from the West side of Electric Avenue. 

Pleasant climbing leads to a well-defined slabby crux.

Bolts

The beginning is a little tricky. Great climb for the grade.  Electric Avenue West Side, just right of The Torii Gate (5.10c).

This is the next-leftmost of the routes on the right (west) side of the area, 3 lines left of the chimney. Bolts with anchor at the top

climbs.name: Frontside 180
climbs.fa: James Foord-Kelcey, Jay Robinson, Kye Egan-Robinson, Tess Egan, Toby Foord-Kelcey

content.description:
10 pitch sport climbing route just south of the Electric Avenue crags. The establishers have published a PDF that contains an excellent description of the route: PDF via squamishclimbingmagazine.ca The route is bolted really well and is the absolute opposite of runout. A very good choice for a first multi pitch endeavor. Descent: please read the section below. The route starts at an obvious west-facing bolted slab, just above the trail in the trees about 30m south of the main Electric Avenue cliffs. 12 quickdraws. You can easily link pitches with a 70m rope. Shorter ropes will also work very likely. You may consider bringing additional alpine draws if you plan on linking. From the top of the last pitch, follow cairns to the summit of Mount Chek, then take the trail on the backside (East) that goes down towards The Monastery and back to Electric Avenue (this descent will be climber's right from the route). Please DO NOT rappel the route, as not only you put others at risk of falling rocks, gear, etc., but it also detracts from the experience and creates chaos for everyone. If you have to bail because of bad weather, dehydration, lack of motivation, etc., you can WALK OFF the route from any the two big terraces that split the route into three tiers: 1) from the base of pitch 4, simply continue walking the trail that put you at the base of the pitch until it takes you back down to Electric Avenue;
2) from the base of pitch 7, walk left towards the Rock of Ages area (clearly visible about 15 meters away), then take it's approach trail back down to Electric Avenue. Both escape descents are climber's left from the route.

Start in the chimney then move slightly right. 

Towards the end of Electric Avenue West Side. 
Bolts with anchor at the top

Location: In the middle of the south-facing wall that is around the corner from the West side of Electric Ave.

Shares first two bolts with Solstice Delirium; go right after second bolt. Slabby start to a more vertical upper half. Looks pretty straightforward but feels a bit more adventurous once you're up there, with some enigmatic holds on the slab and a bit of bobbing and weaving once it gets more vertical. Super fun.

11 bolts, anchors at the top.

climbs.name: Kye’s Stairway to Seven
climbs.fa: Tess Egan, Jay Robinson, Kye Egan-Robinson, September 2017

content.description:
A long 40m route that can be done in two pitches as an introduction to multi-pitch.
Either do two rappels to lower off, or walk off.
Walk off is up further to the trees, then left down a flagged trail.

First route on the farthest left side of the West Face.
14 Bolts

Varied and weird, with easy/moderate slab moves leading to a tenuous couple of steps to the left, followed by the crux sequence of side pulls and smearing feet to a reachy jug. Lots of bolts vey well placed to protect both the crux and short tenuous traverse.

This route is 2 lines left of the chimney.

Bolts

Squamish's Easiest Lead.
Serves as a first pitch for Taiga Feet.

Right side of the West Face, starting to the right of the triangular slab.
4 Bolts

The steep crack that curves up and to right.
Actually better than it looks. 

On the far right side of the East Face is a thin crack that curves up and to the right. 
5 Bolts. Could also lead on gear.

Starts underneath the long undercling. Perform a tricky move to get up into the undercling. Move over the bulge using good holds left of the bolt. Continue up the steep techy slab that has quite good friction. Finish up the easier lower angle slab to the top.

Bolts

Boulder problem start in the left corner of the small roof section. Crux coming around the bulge and may want to extend the third bolt to make clipping easier. Upper section is slopey slab.



Start in the left corner of the roof section 

5 Bolts

climbs.name: Out in the Daytime
climbs.fa: Tess Egan, Jay Robinson, Kye Egan-Robinson, April 2018

content.description:
Fun climb, generously bolted.

Follow broken cracks up to a small bulge, then easy, juggy slab to the anchor.


Third climb from the left on Electric Avenue East Side

Bolts with anchor at the top.

Can easily and safely be lead on gear. Standard rack to 2"

climbs.name: Out in the Night
climbs.fa: Tess Egan, Jay Robinson & Kye Egan-Robinson, April 2018

content.description:
Similar to Out in the Day Time. Follow broken cracks and corners up to an easy, juggy slab. 

Shares a chain anchor with Out in the Day Time.



Farther up the ramp to the right of Out in the Day Time.

11 Bolts. Can easily and safely be lead on gear, Standard Rack to 2"

climbs.name: Out in the Street
climbs.fa: Tess Egan, Jay Robinson, Kye Egan-Robinson, April 2018

content.description:
There are anchor stations at 25m and 30m. 

The second climb from the left on Electric Avenue East Side.
Bolts with anchor at the top

Who says a slab can't be juggy? Bonus points for using no hands. Right route on the triangular slab.
West Face.  7 Bolts

Fun climbing on mostly good holds

Bolts

Slightly more challenging variation to "Then We'll Take it Higher", ending at the mid-point anchors of that route. Starts a couple feet to the right of Then We'll Take it Higher, then curves up and meets the mid way anchor.

Middle of the West Face 8 Bolts

Very short route ending at a good ledge. Middle of the West face, in a short section of clean rock.
Left-most route in the cleaned area. 4 Bolts

Right of Darkness at Teatime and shares first two bolts with The Heel Stone. Moderate terrain leads to a steep section that is difficult to read. The easiest way seems to be moving diagonal up and right. Going straight up seems much harder than 11b although that seems to be where the obvious holds lead you.

14 bolts to chains

climbs.name: St. Elmo's Fire
climbs.fa: Krissy Mackay, Ian Strachan, July 2017 (on gear)

content.description:
Use your whole bag of tricks to chimney, stem, layback and jam your way up the dihedral.

This is the corner route that separates the main middle slab of the West side from the overhangs to the right.  
Gear can supplement the bolts if you brought it and feel the need.

Good arete climb, then transition to the face.

Route to the immediate left of the chimney on the west side
6 bolts to anchor

Excellent fun climbing up the rib. Very popular.

Furthest right route on the West Face.  
12 Bolts

Starts at the top of Misty 9 Step over the chimney and up the slab. Ends at the shared anchor.  Right side of the West Face.
Begins at a mid-height anchor.  10 Bolts

A short and easy route wandering up the triangular slab. 
Slightly harder than it's next door neighbour. 

Left route on the triangular slab. 
7 Bolts

climbs.name: Then We'll Take It Higher
climbs.fa: J. Fieldhouse, K. Fieldhouse, S. Fieldhouse, 2017

content.description:
Fun climb up the rib, generously bolted. Has an optional mid way anchor.

70m rope required to lower off the top.

Fifth climb from the left on Electric Avenue East Side
Bolts with anchor at the top

An easy start with great hands and feet quickly give way to a tiny alcove with a high foot and a (brutal) undercling. Depending on your size, the crux is either pulling the undercling to get onto the great foot, or it's reaching up past the undercling once you've gained the foot to the reachy but solid holds above.

Once you're through, it's big holds or solid feet all the way to the top, with just enough variety and interesting body positions to make it a fun climb to the end.

This is the leftmost of the routes on the right (west) side of the area, 4 lines left of the chimney.

Bolts

Start by heading up a stemming V feature, up to some steep moves on small holds. Crux sequences have rests between them, and the bolts clip from nice stances over nice falls. A fun climb, probably soft in the grade.



5 bolts and fixed draws at the anchor.

A burly boulder problem at the beginning leada to tenuous face climbing above. Doesn't let up until you're at the very top.



To the right of the obvious bolted corner on the East Face (Saint Elmo's Fire, 5.8).

7 draws

5 minute hike from the turnoff to the Conroy Forest Service Road, this crag has lots of easy climbs and can be beginner-climber party central. There are plenty of moderate and more difficult climbs as well, but with its easy access, a high density of climbs in a nice flat belay area, the intro groups will be all over this space for years to come (and with good reason).

East and west facing walls along the belay area make for lots of climbing options in and out of the sun.  The East side faces west (sun in the afternoon), and is mostly slabby routes 5.8 and under with one 5.9.  The West side faces east (shade in the afternoon), and has mostly 5.10 and harder routes, with one or two easier.  If you can get here on a quiet day you can shuffle your rope bag easily down the line of several dozen climbs. It's all sport, and it's all fairly well & generously bolted, though there have been some reports of bolts (I believe anchors) popping on people recently (May 2019). Bring a wrench and pay attention.

Walk a few dozen meters on a trail past the main area to reach Frontside 180, a fantastic multipitch outing of 3 well-bolted and featured pitches each in 3 tiers of rock that brings you to a scenic summit.  

Free Topo available HERE.
